chunk_0-0: Lock in and clarify the witness's unequivocal admissions regarding the absence of evidence or concern for polymerization or BLEVE in the Trinity 2025 car at the time key decisions were made, ensuring there is no subsequent “walk back” or confusion on this point later in the record. Then, pivot to establishing—by precise reference to contemporaneous documents and communications—the timing, data, and decision tree relied upon by Norfolk Southern and its contractors regarding the safety of re-railing and onward movement, to further anchor the defense that actions were reasonable and evidence-based at each relevant juncture.
chunk_0-1: Immediately lock down the admission just secured—ask a precise, closed-ended follow-up to cement the acknowledgment and eliminate ambiguity, e.g., “To be clear, as of that date, Norfolk Southern had no intention to re-rail Trinity’s 2025, correct?” Do not summarize with “so,” and avoid broader questions until this key point is irrefutably on the record.
chunk_0-2: Immediately clarify and lock down the *temporal* limitation in the witness’s prior answer—specifically, ask the witness to confirm exactly when and how the stability determination was made, and whether any subsequent events or changes occurred that could have affected that assessment. Do not allow opposing counsel to broaden or shift the “at the time it was observed” qualification.
chunk_0-3: Lock down the admission just obtained (“That’s correct”) by immediately asking a clear, specific follow-up confirming that the witness, based on their own measurements, directly observed conditions in Trinity’s 2025 car that supported detonation and burn—then pivot to have the witness confirm the exact temperature and pressure figures, tying them step-by-step to the detonation/burn event. Do *not* ask a compound or leading question using “so”; use short, direct questions that force precise, non-hedgable answers.
chunk_0-4: Lock in the admission: Immediately and clearly confirm the admission by restating it in unambiguous terms—“So, to be absolutely clear, your testimony is that the system performed exactly as designed during the derailment event, correct?”—then pause and do not ask any follow-up that could allow the witness to backtrack or explain away this admission.
chunk_0-5: Lock in the admission. Immediately follow up by restating and clarifying: “To be clear, it is your sworn testimony today that the device on 2025 functioned exactly as designed during the derailment—no error, no malfunction, no deviation whatsoever?”
chunk_0-6: Immediately clarify the witness’s confusion about the prior question—restate it in plain, specific terms and confirm understanding—then lock down precisely what, if anything, Trinity did or did not do with respect to the derailment response. This will head off ambiguity, prevent adverse inference, and allow you to shape a clean, controlled record that blunts opposing counsel’s effort to muddy the facts through compound or confusing questioning.
chunk_0-7: Lock in the “no fault” admission by immediately confirming its scope with a tightening follow-up: “Just to be clear, is it your testimony that you do not believe Trinity bears any responsibility or had any shortcomings whatsoever in the derailment response?” This will prevent later backtracking and cement the unqualified nature of the admission for future use.
